Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering, Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China 1 These authors contributed equally. A series of CeO2 catalysts with varying Na content were tested for vapor-phase ketonization of propionic acid at 350 °C. Na+ diffuses into the CeO2 lattice and excess NaOx accumulates on the surface, which dilutes surface contiguous and partially covers Ce-O acid-base pairs. The intrinsic reaction rate in terms of surface area always decreased with increasing Na, likely originated from the altered acid-base property and the increased distance and steric hindrance between enolate and carboxylate for C-C coupling. On the other hand, the stability was significantly improved, with almost no deactivation being observed for Na0.1Ce0.9Ox. This improvement is resulted from the dilution and/or coverage effects of NaOx, which significantly reduces accumulation of inactive bidentate propionate. This work demonstrates a strategy of dilution and/or coverage of surface acid-base pairs by alkaline metal oxides to reduce bidentate carboxylate and therefore to enhance the stability of metal oxide catalysts toward ketonization of carboxylic acids. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CeO2 Sodium doping Propionic acid Ketonization Acid-base pair Biomass conversion Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The renewable and abundant biomass from agricultural residues, forestry and municipal wastes make it an alternative and/or supplementary resource to traditional fossil fuels [1–4]. Catalytic conversion of biomass into valuable chemicals and fuels has been of wide interest [2,3]. Carboxylic acids are one of the major fractions of oxygenated compounds that can be derived from various biomass resources [5]. Carboxylic acids are acidic, corrosive and unstable, and therefore further upgrading is required. Ketonization reaction converts two carboxylic acids into a ketone, eliminating a CO2 and a H2O in the meantime [6]. Compared with hydrodeoxygenation, this reaction does not consume costly hydrogen [7], and the produced ketone may serve as a platform chemical for further conversion [8]. Metal oxide catalysts have been widely explored for ketonization of carboxylic acids [9–12]. Among these oxides, amphoteric metal oxides, such as, TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2, based catalysts show high activity and selectivity [7,13–16]. The Lewis acid-base pairs of Mx+-O2- on the surface of metal oxides serve as the active sites for ketonization [17,18]. The acid/base properties of a metal oxide influence different elementary steps in ketonization, and thus affect the activity. Doping a second metal into CeO2 has been extensively investigated to improve the activity of CeO2 for ketonization [10,11,19,20]. The introduction of a second metal not only modifies the acid-base property, but also may introduce oxygen vacancies in the metal oxide [19,20], and have been proposed to account for the improved ketonization activity [21,22]. The addition of alkali metal to metal oxides have also been reported to improve the activity of ketonization [23]. Parida et al. conducted a comparative investigation on ketonization of acetic acid over alkali hydroxide treated ZrO2 at 250–400 °C [24], and found that the activity decreased following the order of Na > K > Cs > untreated ZrO2 > Li. Ignatchenko et al. explored ketonization on KOH-treated monoclinic ZrO2 and anatase TiO2 catalysts [25]. They found that the KOH-treated anatase TiO2 exhibited higher activity compared to the untreated one for both acetic and isobutyric acids, whereas the enhancement in ketonization of acetic acid over KOH-treated monoclinic ZrO2 was not evident, and the ketonization activity for isobutyric acid was even significantly decreased. Another report from Ignatchenko et al. [26] showed that the stability for ketonization of isobutyric acid and acetone mixtures at 300–500 °C decreased following the order of KOH-treated anatase TiO2 > KOH-treated monoclinic ZrO2 > untreated ZrO2. The patents from the same group also claimed the significant improvement in stability of alkali hydroxide treated TiO2 and ZrO2 for ketonization of carboxylic acids mixture to produce unsymmetrical ketone [27]. These previous works showed that the promotional or detrimental role of alkali metal on metal oxide for ketonization is complex and remains elusive. In addition, few study has been performed for ketonization on alkali metal-doped CeO2. In this contribution, a series of CeO2 catalysts with varying amount of Na doping were prepared, characterized, and investigated for vapor phase ketonization of propionic acid at 350 °C, with the purpose to understand how doping Na can affect the structure of CeO2 and the catalytic performance. The results indicate that diffusion of Na+ into the CeO2 lattice and accumulation of excess NaOx on the surface dilute the contiguous and partially cover the surface Ce-O acid-base pairs, which reduce the density of surface Ce-O pairs and therefore significantly reduce the accumulation of inactive bidentate propionate on the surface, resulting in significantly improved stability at the expense of activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2 was prepared by a precipitation method [28], which was denoted as CeO2-P. For a typical procedure, 2 g of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O was dissolved in 300 mL of deionized water, to which ammonium hydroxide solution was added to adjust the pH value to 8.5. After stirring for 6 h, the precipitate was collected, washed 3 times with water and followed by 3 times with ethanol, dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and finally calcined at 450 °C for 2 h. Na was loaded onto the CeO2-P by an equivalent volume impregnation method using aqueous sodium nitrate solution. The impregnated samples were dried at 100 °C for 24 h, and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The resulting samples were denoted as NayCe1−yOx, where y (in the range of 0.01–0.15) is the molar fraction of Na relative to Na and Ce. For comparison, the CeO2-P sample was calcined again at 500 °C for 2 h. A reference Na/SiO2 sample was also prepared the impregnation method, which was dried at 100 °C for 24 h and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Na and Ce contents in the catalysts were analyzed by an inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Varian). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the CeO2 samples were recorded in a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54056 Å). The 2θ range was 20 ∼ 90° and the scan rate was 4°/min. N2 adsorption was measured using a Micrometrics Tristar 3000 analyzer at liquid N2 temperature. The samples were dried at 90 °C for 1 h and then pretreated with N2 at 300 °C for 3 h. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and pore size distribution was estimated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. High resolution (HR) transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were carried out using a JEM-2100 F microscope operated at 200 kV, with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV and a point resolution of 0.19 nm. The fine powder of catalyst was dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. A droplet of the suspension was added to an ultrathin carbon film supported on a copper mesh for observation. Hydrogen programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was measured on a Chemisorb 2750 (Micrometrics). The catalyst sample (40 mg) was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h in N2. When the sample was cooled to room temperature, the gas was switched from N2 to 5% H2/Ar. After the baseline was stabilized, the temperature was ramped up to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The H2 consumption was monitored by a thermal conductive detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Physical Electronics PHI 1600 system using a 250 W Al Kα radiation. The binding energy (BE) was calibrated by referencing C 1s at 284.8 eV. Raman spectra of CeO2 catalysts were obtained using a DXR spectrometer (Thermo) with an excitation wavelength of 325 nm. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and CO2 (NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD) were also conducted on the Chemisorb 2750. Catalyst sample (100 mg, 40–60 mesh) was pretreated in flowing He (30 mL/min) at 350 °C for 1 h. When the sample was cooled to room temperature, the gas was switched to flowing 5% NH3/He (30 mL/min) at 50 °C or 5% CO2/He (30 mL/min) at 30 °C for 30 min. The sample was purged by flowing He for 60 min to remove physically adsorbed CO2/NH3. Finally, the sample was heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of coke deposition was carried out using a Netzsch STA 499 F3 thermogravimeter. The samples were heated from room temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in flowing air. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Frontier spectrometer equipped with a deuterated tri-glycine sulfate (DTGS) detector and a transmittance cell (Harrick). Self-supporting wafer (50 mg) was pretreated with flowing He (30 mL·min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h. When the sample was cooled to 150 °C, a background spectrum was recorded. Propionic acid (0.06 mL·h−1) vapor was introduced to the cell using a syringe pump for 30 min to saturate the surface of catalyst sample. All lines were heated at 220 °C to prevent any condensation. Physically adsorbed propionic acid was removed by flowing He, and then the temperature was raised to 300 °C at 10 °C/min. The IR spectra were recorded at a resolution of 4 cm−1 with 32 scans. The FTIR spectra of CO2 adsorption at room temperature were also recorded using a similar procedure described above. 2.3 Catalytic performance Vapor phase ketonization of propionic acid was evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor with an outer diameter of 6 mm at atmospheric pressure [29–32]. Catalyst samples (40–60 mesh) were placed between two layers of quartz wool in the center of the reactor. The samples were pretreated in flowing Ar (30 mL·min−1) for 30 min at 350 °C. Propionic acid was injected to the reaction system using a syringe pump (KDS100, KD scientific). All lines were heated to avoid condensation. The products were quantified on-line by a gas chromatograph (GC 7890B, Agilent) equipped with an HP-INNOwax column (60 m × 320 µm × 0.5 µm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Selectivity (%) for 3-pentanone was defined as 100 × 2 × moles of 3-pentanone produced/moles of propionic acid converted. The turnover frequency (TOF) of ketonization was calculated in terms of the measured density of acid-base pair under differential condition. The density of acid-base pair was measured by titration of aldol condensation of acetone at 180 °C in the same reactor [17,18]. Varying amount of propionic acid was added to the feed of acetone. When the concentration of propionic acid in the feed was higher than a certain value, the conversion of acetone dropped to zero. The density of acid-base pair was calculated assuming that all acid-base pair sites were occupied by propionic acid and one propionic acid molecule occupied two surface acid-base pairs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization It is not surprising that the ICP measured Na contents matched closely with the targeted values ( Table 1), since the catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method. The crystal structures of CeO2-P and Na-doped CeO2 catalysts were analyzed by XRD ( Fig. 1). All samples exhibited diffractions at 2θ of 28.5, 33.0, 47.4, 56.2, 58.9, 69.3, 76.7 and 79.1°, which correspond to the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS 34–0394). Notably, no diffractions of Na2O2, Na2O and Na2CO3 are observable for Na-doped catalysts, pointing to the high dispersion of Na species. These results are consistent with previous reports using similar catalyst preparation techniques [28,33,34]. The corresponding lattice parameters are summarized in Table 1. At low Na doping (≤ 0.05), the lattice parameter experiences an expansion from 5.404 Å to 5.415 Å. This phenomenon can be described by the Vegard's law [35] using the following equation (see Fig. S1): ∆ d Ce = ( 0.0220 ∆ r k + 0.00015 ∆ z k ) m k where, ∆dCe (nm) is the variation of lattice parameter, ∆rk (nm) is the difference in ionic radius, ∆zk is the valence difference, and mk (%) is the mole percentage of the doped oxide. This expansion can be interpreted by the substitution of Ce4+ ions (0.97 Å) by Na+ ions (1.18 Å) with larger diameter took place during calcination [36], which point to the migration of Na+ into the CeO2 lattice. When the loading of Na is higher than 0.05, the lattice parameter keeps almost constant. This observation suggests that the Na fraction of 0.05 is a critical point. When Na fraction is higher than 0.05, excess NaOx species accumulates on the surface of CeO2, and these excess surface NaOx should have little influence on the lattice parameter of the bulk catalyst. In addition, the XRD patterns of spent CeO2 and Na0.1Ce0.9Ox catalysts (Fig. S2) were almost identical to the respective fresh ones, suggesting that ketonization happens on the surface instead of bulk of CeO2 based catalysts under current reaction conditions. The result also confirmed that the crystal structure is stable during ketonization. The BET surface area and BJH pore volume and size of Na doped CeO2 samples are presented in Table 1. Compared with the surface area of 52.0 m2·g−1 for CeO2-P, it increased moderately to >60 m2·g−1 for loading small amount of Na, i.e., ≤0.05. This result can be attributed to the expansion of pores caused by migration of Na into the CeO2 lattice, which is similar to CeO2 doped with different metal oxides [34,37,38]. However, further increase of Na loading resulted in a gradual decrement in surface area, which decreased to 45.1 m2·g−1 for Na0.15Ce0.85Ox. This is likely resulted from excess NaOx species stayed on the surface of catalyst, leading to partial blockage of the pores. The morphology and fine structure of the Na doped CeO2 were examined by TEM. All samples showed hexagonal shape with sizes of 25–50 nm ( Fig. 2). HR-TEM images of all samples revealed lattice spacing of 0.306 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of cubic fluorite CeO2 [39,40], which is consistent with the XRD result. Notably, the hexagonal boundaries gradually became blurred with increasing Na, which suggests the coverage of the surface by NaOx species at high loadings. However, no clear lattice spacing is observable for NaOx species in these samples. Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox ( Fig. 3) showed that Na species are homogenously dispersed in the particle. H2-TPR was conducted to explore the surface structure and reducibility of the Na doped CeO2. As shown in Fig. 4, CeO2-P displayed two reduction peaks centered at 441 and 710 °C, which are assignable to reduction of surface and bulk of CeO2, respectively [21]. Doping Na resulted in a slight shift of these peaks to higher temperatures. One possible explanation is that Na species hinders the dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on surface Ce-O pairs [28]. In addition, a new peak at slightly lower temperature (347–480 °C) immerged and increased in intensity with increasing Na, indicating this peak is related with the reduction of NaOx species [36]. Note that the intensity of this peak became obvious when the fraction of Na is ≥ 0.05, which suggests the reduction of excess NaOx species on the surface of catalyst [36]. The NaOx species enhances the alkalinity, which may result in more carbonate species [28] and hence shift the reduction to higher temperatures with increasing Na. The surface composition and chemical structure of CeO2-P and Na0.1Ce0.9Ox were characterized by XPS ( Fig. 5). Compared with CeO2-P (Fig. 5a), the survey spectra of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox (Fig. 5b) confirmed the presence of Na. The surface atomic percentage of Na is 5.5%, which corresponds to a Na/(Na+Ce) ratio of 0.2227. This value is much higher than the ICP measured ratio of 0.089, suggesting the aggregation of Na species on the surface of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox. The Ce 3d XPS spectrum can be divided into eight peaks (Fig. 5c), with peaks of V and U being assigned to Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2, respectively. Peaks of V, V″, V‴ and U, U″, U‴ are characteristic peaks of Ce4+, while peaks of V′ and U′ are characteristic peaks of Ce3+ [38]. The relative concentration of Ce3+, estimated from the peak area ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+), is determined to be 16.4% for Na0.1Ce0.9Ox. This value is higher than that of CeO2-P (13.2%). The O 1 s spectra (Fig. 5d) displayed lattice oxygen (OL) at 528.8 eV, O2- ions in close proximity to surface oxygen vacancies (OV) at 531.1 eV, and chemisorbed oxygen (OC) at 532.2 eV [13,38,41,42]. The concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, i.e., OV/(OV+OC+OL) ratio, for Na0.1Ce0.9Ox (15.9%) is higher than that for CeO2-P (12.7%). Collectively, these results indicate the substitution of Ce4+ by Na+ produced more oxygen vacancies or coordinatively unsaturated Ce3+ ions, due to charge compensation. The formation of oxygen vacancies upon Na doping was also investigated by Raman spectroscopy ( Fig. 6). The peak centered at 461.0 cm−1 corresponds to the F2 g symmetric stretching vibration mode of cubic CeO2, which is the characteristic for the fluorite cubic structure [43–45]. The defect-induced (D) vibrational mode is observed at 600 cm−1, resulting from the anion defects in the ceria lattice [46]. The band centered at 1171 cm−1 is attributed to the second overtone of the longitudinal optical (2LO) band, and the band at 1747 cm−1 is the third overtone of the longitudinal optical (3LO) band [47]. The appearance of LO bands is due to the multiphonon excitation of Raman resonance effect. The integral band intensity ratio of D to F2 g (ID/IF2g) reflects the relative concentration of oxygen vacancy [37]. The quantified ID/IF2g ratio (Table 1) increases with increasing Na to 0.05, and then keeps constant with further increasing Na content, which again indicates that the Na fraction of 0.05 is a critical point for Na+ entering the CeO2 lattice. The value of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox (1.37) is higher than that of CeO2-P (1.13), suggesting the presence of more vacancies for the former sample. To determine the basicity of Na doped CeO2, CO2 adsorption at room temperature was followed by in situ IR spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 7a, a broad absorption band centered at 3416 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of bridging hydroxyl. A tiny band at 1050 cm−1 is assigned to the C-O stretching vibration of bicarbonate [48], which is resulted from CO2 adsorption on weak basic site of hydroxyl groups [49]. The bands of stretching vibration of various types carbonates are present in the region of 1200–1600 cm−1 [48,50–52], i.e., monodentate carbonate at 1320 cm−1, chelating bidentate carbonate at 1575 cm−1, and polydentate carbonate at 1378 cm−1. The chelating bidentate carbonate is originated from CO2 adsorption on intermediate strength basic sites of Ce-O acid-base pair, while monodentate and polydentate carbonates are resulted from CO2 adsorption on strong basic site of under coordinated O anions [48]. The normalized integral band intensities of various carbonates in terms of both mass and surface area are reported in Fig. 7b, S3 and Table S1. Although the mass based integral band intensity of overall carbonates shows a maximum at Na loading of 2–5% (Fig. S3), the surface area based integral band intensity of overall carbonates increase quickly at Na loading < 2% and then slowly at Na loading > 2% (Fig. 7b). This result indicates that the surface basic site increases with increasing Na loadings. Note that the bidentate carbonate shows a maximum at Na loading of 2–5%, while the monodentate and polydentate carbonates always increase with loading of Na, indicating that the increased strong basic sites (O anions) are related with NaOx species on the surface. The decreased density of basic sites with intermediate strength (bidentate carbonate) at high Na loadings (> 0.05) also reflects the coverage of surface Ce-O pairs by NaOx species. To further explore the influence of Na doping on the acid-base properties, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD were performed. The profiles of CO2-TPD ( Fig. 8a) display three regions, i.e., < 200, 200–400 and 400–700 °C, which are related with basic sites of weak, intermediate and strong strength, respectively. Similarly, the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 8b) show two regions of < 200 and 200–400 °C assignable to weak and intermediate strength acid sites, respectively. It is evident that the weak basic sites decrease while the strong basic sites increase with increasing Na loadings (Fig. 8a and Table 2). Consistent with FTIR of CO2 adsorption results, this trend indicates that the gradual displacement of basic sites related with CeO2 by NaOx. Differently, both the weak and intermediate strength acid sites decrease gradually to almost zero with increasing Na loadings (Fig. 8b and Table 2), confirming the acid sites (Ce cations) were gradually diluted and covered by NaOx species. Interestingly, we note that only weak acid sites are present for Na0.1Ce0.9Ox, likely suggesting significant coverage and modification of the property of surface Ce cations by adjacent NaOx species. Fig. 9 shows the conversion of acetone as a function of propionic acid/acetone ratio during titration at 180 °C. It is apparent that the conversion of acetone decreases linearly with increasing propionic acid/acetone molar ratio, which indicates the occupation of surface acid-base pairs by propionic acid, leading to lowered aldol condensation activity. When the propionic acid/acetone ratio reached 0.051 and 0.042 on CeO2 and Na0.1Ce0.9Ox, respectively, the conversion of acetone decreased to zero. Accordingly, densities of acid-base pairs on CeO2 and Na0.1Ce0.9Ox are determined to be 3.42 and 3.15 nm−2, respectively. The decrement in surface density of acid-base pairs upon doping Na reflects the dilution and/or coverage of surface Ce cations by NaOx, which increases density of surface basic sites (O species associated with NaOx) but decreases surface acid sites (Ce cations), and eventually decreases the density of acid-base pairs. To clarify the adsorption configuration of propionic acid and its reactivity toward ketonization on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox, propionic acid adsorption at 150 °C followed by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) was monitored by in situ FTIR. The FTIR spectrum of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox ( Fig. 10) at 150 °C shows that the surface was saturated by dissociated propionic acid with both monodentate (antisymmetric (νas) and symmetric vibrational (νs) at 1567 and 1433 cm−1, respectively) and bidentate (νas and νs at 1534 and 1475 cm−1, respectively) configurations [13,19,21]. In addition, C−H bending vibrations (δC-H) at 1381 cm−1, O−H bending vibrations (δO-H) at 1298 cm−1, and C−H in-plane rocking vibration (ρC-H) at 1080 cm−1 of adsorbed propionic acid were also present [19,53]. The band intensities of propionates decreased with increasing desorption temperature. When the temperature was > 200 °C, the bands associated with aldol dimer (4-methyl-5-ethyl-5-hydroxy-3-heptanone) and dehydrated aldol dimer (4-methyl-5-ethyl-4-hepten-3-one) from further aldol condensation of 3-pentanone appeared. Specifically, CO stretching vibration (νC O) at 1545 cm−1, CC stretching vibration (νC C) at 1515 cm−1, and δC-H at 1368 cm−1 are related with dehydrated aldol dimer. The bands at 1415 cm−1 and 1608–1627 cm−1 are likely attributable to δC-H and νC O of -CH2-CO group for the aldol dimer, respectively [54,55]. These bands also present for CeO2-P with different intensities [21]. Since the νs bands of monodentate and bidentate propionates are overlapped with the bands of the aldol dimer from 3-pentanone [13], the νas bands of monodentate and bidentate propionates on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox and CeO2-P were integrated and plotted as a function of desorption temperature ( Fig. 11a and b). For both samples, the intensity of bidentate propionate was much stronger than that of monodentate propionate, suggesting bidentate propionate is the dominant surface species. In addition, the intensity monodentate propionate decreased much faster than that of bidentate propionate with increasing desorption temperature, which is clearly visualized when the band intensities were normalized to those at 150 °C (Fig. 11c and d). This result indicates although monodentate configuration is the minor surface species, it is likely the more reactive configuration toward ketonization [13]. Interestingly, the band intensities of both configurations were much lower on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox relative to CeO2-P. Compare with CeO2-P, the intensity monodentate propionate on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox was reduced to ∼1/2, while the bidentate propionate was reduced more strongly to ∼1/4. Consistent with the measured density of acid-base pairs by titration, this result also reflects the partial coverage of surface Ce-O pairs by NaOx species. One may expect the Na species in and/or on the surface dilutes the contiguous surface Ce-O pairs, which affect the bidentate configuration more strongly than that of monodentate one, since the former configuration requires two Ce-O acid-base pairs in close proximity while the latter configuration only requires a Ce-O acid-base pair. Moreover, the relative monodentate propionate band intensity of CeO2-P decreases faster than that of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox, which likely reflects the higher reactivity of CeO2-P toward ketonization. 3.2 Ketonization of propionic acid Fig. 12 compares the dependence of propionic acid conversion on NayCe1−yOx samples with varying Na content at 350 °C and a constant space time (W/F) of 0.05 h, which is defined as the weight of catalyst (W, g) to organic feed flow rate (F, g/h). The CeO2-P exhibited a propionic acid conversion of 10.6%. The conversion kept almost constant when the Na content was < 0.05, while it decreased almost linearly with increasing Na content when Na was ≥ 0.05. In addition, the 3-pentanone selectivity started to decrease from 100% when Na was > 0.1, and decreased to 81.3% for Na0.15Ce0.85Ox. The by-products were mainly propionic anhydride, which is formed from dehydration of two propionic acids [18], possibly on basic sites of NaOx species on the surface. This result also implies the accumulation of NaOx species on the surface at high loadings, which covers the surface Ce-O pairs and changes product distributions. To clarify the activity of NaOx for ketonization, a reference Na/SiO2 sample with a Na/(Na+Si) ratio of 0.02 was also tested for ketonization under identical reaction condition. As shown in Fig. S4, the conversion of propionic acid was only 1.5% with selectivities of 73.2% and 26.8% toward 3-pentanone and propionic anhydride, respectively. Note that the Na0.02Ce0.98Ox with same amount Na displayed a conversion of 10.6%. Such significant difference implies bare NaOx species has little activity toward ketonization and favors the formation of propionic anhydride via intermolecular dehydration, likely resulting from weak Lewis acidity of Na cations while strong basicity of O anions. The intrinsic reaction rate in terms of mass ( Table 3), which was measured under differential conditions with conversion < 12% by varying W/F, showed a similar trend as the conversions reported in Fig. 12. While, when the intrinsic reaction rate was normalized to the surface area, it always decreased with increasing Na content (Table 3). This difference is resulted from the initial decrease in activity at small amount of Na (< 0.05) is compensated by the increase in surface area. This result indicates that the activity of the active center on the surface of catalyst is decreased upon doing Na. To confirm this, the turnover frequency (TOF) in terms of density of acid-base pair measured by titration was estimated. The TOFs are 7.26 and 4.88 s−1 on CeO2-P and Na0.1Ce0.9Ox, respectively, indicating the activity of Ce-O pair is significantly decreased due to the presence of adjacent NaOx species, which modifies the property of Ce-O pair in close proximity. The stability of NayCe1−yOx catalysts for ketonization of propionic acid was tested at 350 °C for 8.5 h. The W/F was adjusted in the range of 0.05–0.18 h for NayCe1−yOx with varying Na content to achieve a similar initial conversion of ∼10%. As shown in Fig. 13, the CeO2-P displayed the quickest deactivation, with the conversion of propionic acid being decreased to 2.8% at 8.5 h. The stability was improved with increasing Na content. Specifically, the conversion dropped to 4.4%, 5.4%, and 7.8% on Na0.01Ce0.99Ox, Na0.02Ce0.98Ox, and Na0.05Ce0.95Ox, respectively. When the Na content was increased further to ≥0.10, almost no deactivation was observed during the 8.5 h reaction. Taking both activity and stability into account, the Na0.1Ce0.9Ox appears to be the optimal catalyst for ketonization. To confirm the better stability of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox over Na0.08Ce0.92Ox, the stability test was performed at a longer W/F of 0.5 h to increase the initial conversion. As shown in Fig. S5, the conversion over Na0.1Ce0.9Ox is almost constant at 36% throughout the test, while the conversion over Na0.08Ce0.92Ox decreased from 52% at the beginning of reaction to 28% at 8.5 h, confirming Na0.1Ce0.9Ox is the optimal catalyst. To explore the reason accounting for the improved stability with Na addition, the used samples after 36 h reaction with a W/F of 0.05 h at 350 °C were tested with TG analysis. As shown in Fig. 14, the DTG curve of CeO2-P showed two peaks at 227 and 304 °C, respectively. While, Na0.1Ce0.9Ox only showed two tiny peaks at much lower temperatures of 179 and 241 °C. Moreover, the quantified amount of coke deposition (weight loss at temperature > 100 °C) on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox (2.0%) was only half of that on CeO2-P (3.6%). Collectively, these results indicate that optimal amount of Na doping significantly reduced the heavier coke deposition during ketonization, which led to significantly enhanced stability. 3.3 Discussion Lattice parameter analysis from the XRD results (Fig. S1 and Table 1) clearly showed the lattice expansion of CeO2 upon Na doping, which indicates the migration of Na cations from surface into the lattice of CeO2 during calcination at 500 °C. To balance the charge induced by Na cations, additional oxygen vacancies are expected to form in the NayCe1−yOx [34], as supported by the XPS (Fig. 5) and Raman (Fig. 6) results. Collectively, these results confirm the diffusion of Na+ into the lattice of CeO2. An earlier investigation suggested that the Na+ (ionic radius of 1.18 Å) readily incorporates into the lattice of CeO2 during calcination at temperature > 400 °C, likely due to the high ionic potential and similar ionic radius to Ce4+ (0.97 Å) [56]. Ang et al. also concluded the diffusion of Na+ into the CeO2 lattice by observing the lattice expansion through XRD [36]. When the Na content is > 0.05, excess NaOx species stay on the surface, which partially covers the catalyst surface and hence reduces the surface area (Table 1). These surface NaOx species has little influence on the lattice parameter of bulk catalyst and the content of oxygen vacancy, which are supported by the XRD and Raman results (Table 1), respectively. In addition, the accumulation of NaOx at high Na loadings (> 0.05) was also confirmed by the observation of amorphous surface species on catalyst particle by TEM (Fig. 2) and the presence of reduction peak of NaOx in H2-TPR (Fig. 4) As shown in Scheme 1, these results allow us to conclude the diffusion of Na+ into the lattice at low Na loading (< 0.05) and the accumulation of excess NaOx on the surface at high Na loadings (> 0.05). On the other hand, doping Na enhances the basicity of the catalyst, as evidenced by the FTIR of CO2 adsorption (Fig. 7) and CO2-TPD (Fig. 8a). The diffusion of Na+ into CeO2 lattice breaks the contiguous of surface Ce-O pairs (Scheme 1). Moreover, the coverage of excess NaOx species on the surface reduces accessible density of Ce-O acid-base pairs (Scheme 1) while providing more strong basic sites (O anions related with NaOx). In addition, the dilution and coverage effects also reduced the density of acid site (Ce cations), as evidenced by NH3-TPD (Fig. 8b). It is now generally accepted that the moderate strength acid-base pairs are the active sites for ketonization of carboxylic acids [13,18,21]. The basic sites (O anions) enables α-H abstraction from a carboxylic acid to form an enolate, which nucleophilically attacks the carboxylic carbon of another vicinal carboxylic acid (C-C coupling) to form a β-ketoacid intermediate, and eventually decomposes a ketone [6,17,57]. Both enolization and C-C coupling steps are crucial for ketonization, and C-C coupling is normally believed to be the rate limiting step. Note that the acid sites (Ce cations) play the role of stabilization of the carboxylic acid and reaction intermediates during the turnover. The properties of acid and base sites may influence different elementary steps involved in ketonization. Hence, the balance between the acid and base sites, as well as the surface configuration of acid-base pairs are crucial to achieve high activity for ketonization [19,58,59]. The presence of oxygen vacancies has been reported to improve the ketonization activity by stabilizing the intermediates of transition states [22,60]. Although the content of oxygen vacancy increased upon doping Na to CeO2, the ketonization activity in terms of surface area decreased (Table 3). In particular, the TOF of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox (4.88 s−1) is much lower than that of CeO2-P (7.26 s−1 on), although the content of oxygen vacancy is higher for the former sample. This result indicates that the oxygen vacancy plays a minor role in ketonization under current reaction condition. On the other hand, the enhanced basicity of O anions due to NaOx species (see FTIR of CO2 adsorption and CO2-TPD) may enhance abstraction of the weakly acidic α-H of propionic acid. Indeed, Ignatchenko et al. [25] observed the increased H/D exchange activity between the α-H of isobutyric acid and D2O on KOH modified monoclinic ZrO2, and ascribed the improved ketonization to the increased enolization activity. However, the ketonization TOF on Na doped CeO2 was much lower than that on CeO2-P. This contradiction in turn indicates that the enolization is not the rate limiting step. Although the activity of enolization is improved, the overall activity is limited by C-C coupling step [18], which is reduced likely due to the unbalanced acid-base property and/or increased steric hindrance. CeO2 is an amphoteric metal oxide, which shows weaker acidity while stronger basicity compared with TiO2 and ZrO2. Doping Na further increases the basicity while reducing acidity (Fig. 8), which may disfavor the elementary steps other than enolization, such as C-C coupling and reprotonation. In addition, the dilution of contiguous Ce-O pairs by Na in the surface and/or coverages of Ce-O pairs by NaOx on the surface likely increases the distance and/or places steric hindrance between the enolate and adjacent carboxylate (Scheme 1), which makes C-C coupling step difficult. Moreover, the dilution and/or coverage effects also reduced the density of surface acid-base pairs. Consequently, the overall activity of ketonization was reduced upon doping Na to CeO2. Despite the activity was reduced, the stability of ketonization was significantly improved, with almost no deactivation being observed when Na content was ≥0.1 (Fig. 13). It has been proposed that the accumulation of inactive bidentate carboxylate on the surface is the major reason that accounts for the deactivation of metal oxide catalyst during ketonization [17,18]. The FTIR results of propionic adsorption indicate that the dilution and/or coverage of surface Ce-O pairs reduced the density of surface propionates, with the bidentate propionate being more strongly reduced than the monodentate one (Fig. 11a and b). Additionally, the bidentate propionate on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox was more readily removed during TPD than that on CeO2-P (Fig. 11d). These behaviors are evidently resulted from the reduced density of Ce-O pairs as well as the reduced acidity due to the dilution and coverage effects of NaOx. Consequently, accumulation of inactive bidentate propionic acid on the surface of Na0.1Ce0.9Ox was retarded (Scheme 1), which may inhibit its further condensation to heavier products, i.e., coke precursors, resulting in reduced coke deposition (Fig. 14) and significantly improved stability. 4 Conclusion A series of CeO2 catalysts with varying Na content have been prepared and tested for vapor phase ketonization of propionic acid. Doping Na results in diffusion of Na+ into CeO2 lattice at low Na/(Ce+Na) ratio of < 0.05, and accumulation of excess NaOx on the surface of catalyst at high Na/(Ce+Na) ratio of >0.05, resulting in dilution of contiguous surface Ce-O pairs by Na in the surface and partial coverages of Ce-O acid-base pairs by NaOx on the surface. Doping Na also enhanced the basicity of CeO2 at the expense of acidity, and increased density of oxygen vacancy. The intrinsic reaction rate in terms of surface area always decreased with the amount of Na doping. Moreover, the TOF of ketonization in terms of acid-base pair decreased significantly from 7.26 s−1 on CeO2-P to 4.88 s−1 on Na0.1Ce0.9Ox. Such decrement cannot be ascribed to increased oxygen vacancy or basicity, but likely to altered acid-base property and increased distance and steric hindrance between C-C coupling of enolate and carboxylate due to the presence of NaOx in and/or on the surface. On the other hand, the stability was significantly improved, with almost no deactivation being observed for Na0.1Ce0.9Ox. This improvement in stability is resulted from the dilution and/or coverage effects, which significantly reduce the accumulation of inactive bidentate propionate on the surface. This work demonstrated that the strategy of dilution and/or coverage of surface acid-base pairs by alkaline metal oxides to reduce the accumulation of inactive bidentate carboxylate is an effective approach to enhance the stability of metal oxide catalysts toward ketonization of carboxylic acids. coredata.dc:description: A series of CeO2 catalysts with varying Na content were tested for vapor-phase ketonization of propionic acid at 350 °C. Na+ diffuses into the CeO2 lattice and excess NaOx accumulates on the surface, which dilutes surface contiguous and partially covers Ce-O acid-base pairs. The intrinsic reaction rate in terms of surface area always decreased with increasing Na, likely originated from the altered acid-base property and the increased distance and steric hindrance between enolate and carboxylate for C-C coupling. On the other hand, the stability was significantly improved, with almost no deactivation being observed for Na0.1Ce0.9Ox. This improvement is resulted from the dilution and/or coverage effects of NaOx, which significantly reduces accumulation of inactive bidentate propionate. This work demonstrates a strategy of dilution and/or coverage of surface acid-base pairs by alkaline metal oxides to reduce bidentate carboxylate and therefore to enhance the stability of metal oxide catalysts toward ketonization of carboxylic acids.
coredata.dc:title: Role of Na in the stability enhancement of CeO2 catalysts for ketonization of propionic acid
